title: 111_hr681
content: H.R. 681 was introduced in the 111th Congress to amend the Digital Television Transition and Public Safety Act of 2005 and the Communications Act of 1934. The bill aimed to establish a new digital television transition date, improve the digital-to-analog converter box program, and address other related purposes. On January 26, 2009, Mr. Waxman introduced a bill in the House of Representatives to amend the Digital Television Transition and Public Safety Act of 2005 and the Communications Act of 1934. The bill aimed to establish a new digital television transition date, improve the digital-to-analog converter box program, and address other purposes. The "Digital Television Transition Extension Act of 2009" extends the DTV transition deadline. Amendments are made to the Communications Act of 1934 and the Digital Television Transition and Public Safety Act of 2005, changing dates from February to June and March to July in various sections. The Federal Communications Commission extends license terms for recovered spectrum by 116 days, changing dates from February to June and March to July in various sections of the Acts. The Federal Communications Commission extends license terms for recovered analog spectrum. The Federal Communications Commission extends license terms for recovered analog spectrum, including modification of the Digital-to-Analog Converter Box Program. The Digital Television Transition and Public Safety Act of 2005 is amended to allow for replacement coupons for expired ones. Additionally, delivery of coupons will be expedited through first-class mail within 7 days of the Act's enactment. The Department of Commerce will speed up coupon distribution under the Digital Television Transition and Public Safety Act of 2005 by using pre-sorted first class mail. Amendments to the Act require new budget authority before taking effect. The implementation of the Digital Television Transition and Public Safety Act of 2005 will be expedited by the Department of Commerce through the use of pre-sorted first class mail. Amendments to the Act necessitate new budget authority before being implemented. The Act allows television broadcast stations to terminate analog signals early if done in accordance with FCC requirements, including flexible procedures for digital conversion. The FCC permits the use of cleared spectrum for public safety radio services if a television broadcast station stops analog broadcasting before June 12, 2009, and certain spectrum becomes available as a result. The FCC allows the use of cleared spectrum for public safety radio services if a television station stops analog broadcasting before June 12, 2009. The Commission determines that such use is in the public interest and does not cause harmful interference to television stations. The FCC is authorized to use expedited procedures to make a determination on applications from public safety agencies to begin using the spectrum within 2 weeks. The Telecommunications and Information Administration must adopt or revise rules within 30 days of this Act's enactment to implement its provisions and purposes. SEC. 5 extends the Commission's auction authority to 2012. SEC. 6 requires reports to be submitted. Monthly reporting requirement starting one month after the Act's enactment until October 31, 2009. The Assistant Secretary must provide monthly reports to specific committees detailing unredeemed coupons, replacement coupons issued, and available converter boxes for purchase by consumers. The Federal Communications Commission must report on the number of new and replacement coupons issued, remaining funds for the Digital Television Transition and Public Safety Act, and the impact on rural areas by December 30, 2009. The Transportation of the Senate requires a report on the impact of the digital television transition on consumers in rural areas in the United States. The report must include information on service disruptions, broadcast coverage gaps, and recommendations for addressing problems in rural areas.
